1005 SILVER CREEK RD,
MARQUETTE, MI, 49855-8951
Re: License #: CI520304229
Special Investigation Report #: 2023C0000720SI
Dear Ms. Koziara:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Stephanie S Meeuwenberg, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff
Section The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth attempted to hang himself on 7/16/23, 8/15/23 and 8/26/23.
Youth has either been found attempting to hang himself or has
been cut down from the ligature. Youth has been on the roof and
in trees attempting to jump and kill himself. Youth needs a higher
level of supervision. There are concerns that if youth remain at the
facility, youth will successfully commit suicide.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant 1 was interviewed via telephone on August 31,
2023, in collaboration with the MDHHS worker. Complainant 1
said she did not have any additional information, noting that most
of the information came directly from Youth A. Complainant 1 said
she had concerns that whenever she responded to Teaching
Family Homes the staff never provided any additional information
regarding the youth and would rarely talk to the emergency
responders.
2

Complainant 2 was interviewed via telephone on September
6, 2023. Complainant 2 did not have anything additional
information.
Youth A was interviewed via TEAMS on August 30, 2023, in
collaboration with the MDHHS worker. Youth A said he was
placed at South Bluff since May 25, 2023, and is currently at
Willow Creek Hospital since August 26, 2023. Youth A said prior to
going to South Bluff he was interviewed and shared his past
suicidal ideations with Therapist and Supervisor, so he felt the
staff were aware of his history and prior “hanging attempts”. Youth
A said he does not feel the staff care about him and reported staff
do not do anything to stop him from hurting himself. Youth A said
within the first three weeks of being placed at South Bluff he tried
to hang himself in a tree and staff did “nothing” and he slipped out
of the tie and fell to the ground. Youth A said he does not
remember which staff was present, which day it was, or the time of
the day. Youth A said on the same day he again tried to hang
himself in a tree by the main building and Staff 6 and Chief
Administrator got him down and he went to the emergency room
and was evaluated but then sent back to South Bluff. Youth A said
he had other self-harm behaviors such as cutting his arm with a
butter knife and syrup cap and staff did not stop him and he
stopped himself. Youth A was not able to remember when these
incidents occurred or who was around at the time. Youth A said on
August 15, 2023, he was trying to hang himself at the pavilion with
his sweater and Staff 3 and Staff 4 were with him. Youth A said
Staff 3 was trying to untie the sweater to get him done but he was
“fighting” so she was unable to. Youth A said Staff 4 was able to
untie the sweater and get him down. Youth A said once he was
down on the picnic table, he grabbed the metal grill brush to hurt
himself but one of the staff took it away from him. Youth A said he
sat on the table until the police arrived, and they walked him to the
ambulance who took him to the hospital for an evaluation. Youth A
said he was sent from the hospital to Willow Creek Hospital from
August 16, 2023, until August 25, 2023. Youth A said on August
26, 2023, he had spent the day at the YMCA and upon his return
to the house he “got anxious” and was talking to Staff 6 for about
forty-five minutes however that did not help and so he got his
sweater and went to the pavilion to hang himself. Youth A said
Staff 6 was with him when he ran over to the pavilion and hung
himself but she could not get him down alone. She called for Staff
2. Youth A said Staff 2 ran over and picked him up and got him
down and laid him on the table. Youth A said he lost
consciousness during this incident. Youth A said the police were
called and when they arrived, he talked to them, and they then
3

walked him to the ambulance who brought him to the hospital for
an evaluation. Youth A said he was sent to Willow Creek Hospital
where he currently is placed. Youth A said every time he gets
upset the staff will try to talk to him, offer for him to call his support
people off his list, talk to Therapist, or use his coping skills but he
never uses any of those tools because he “doesn’t want to”. Youth
A said he is able to see Therapist one to two times per week.
Youth A said he signed a safety plan when he returned to South
Bluff from Willow Creek but did not recall what the plan stated.
Youth A said staff “followed me wherever I go” and he was never
allowed out of staff supervision. Youth A said staff checked on him
“all the time” when he was in his room.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on August
31, 2023, in collaboration with the MDHHS worker. Youth B
said Youth A is not nice to him and calls him names. Youth B said
Youth A “self-harms and goes to the hospital”. Youth B said he has
never witnessed Youth A doing any self-harm acts. Youth B said
staff “watch [Youth A] closely” and will “do extra checks when
[Youth A] is in his room”.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on August
31, 2023, in collaboration with the MDHHS worker. Youth C
said Youth A told him he does not like the rules or any of the staff
at South Bluff. Youth C said Youth A “hurts himself” but that he had
never witnessed it firsthand. Youth C said when Youth A returned
from Willow Creek Hospital, he told Youth C he wanted to go back
because he got “pop everyday and had a lot of friends” there.
Youth C said on August 25, 2023, he saw Youth A grab a blanket
and walk out of the house and say he was going to go hang
himself so he could go back to the hospital. Youth C said staff
“watch [Youth A] closely all the time”.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility, on August
31, 2023, in collaboration with the MDHHS worker. Staff 1 said
Youth A has exhibited high risk behaviors since being placed at
South Bluff. Staff 1 said within the first two weeks of being placed,
Youth A laid in the road and refused to move and when he finally
got up, he climbed on the roof and refused to come down,
resulting in police contact to assist. Staff 1 said on July 16, 2023,
Youth A ran over to the main building “site” from South Bluff and
Staff 5 requested her assistance, so she ran to help Staff 5. Staff 1
said when she arrived at the main building Youth A was standing
on the railing trying to tie his sweatshirt on a gutter and Staff 5 was
holding his legs. Staff 1 said Youth A jumped down and put Staff 5
into a “choke hold” with his knee pressing in Staff 5’s stomach
4

stating he could “kill” Staff 5 if he wanted. Staff 1 said she got
Youth A’s sweatshirt and tried to get him off of Staff 5. Staff 1 said
Youth A finally stopped, sat down and refused to speak to either
her or Staff 5. Staff 1 said Youth A suddenly got up and ran down
the hill into the woods and staff lost sight of him almost
immediately. Staff 1 said the police were contacted and they found
Youth A and brought him back to South Bluff. Staff 1 said Youth A’s
room was cleared of all items and since his placement he has had
several behavior plans and safety plans. Staff 1 said the newest
safety plan was developed on August 25, 2023 which only allows
Youth A the clothing he is wearing and nothing extra. Staff 1 said
she has been given a lot of information on Youth A’s history and
feels she has been trained well on how to manage Youth A’s
behaviors.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility, on August
31, 2023, in collaboration with the MDHHS worker. Staff 2 said
Youth A has struggled with self-harm and suicidal ideations since
his placement at South Bluff and he has been directly involved in
two incidents with Youth A. Staff 2 said within a week of being
placed at South Bluff Youth A became upset and went outside to a
tree and threatened to hang himself. Staff 2 said he climbed the
tree Youth A was in and took the sweatshirt and sat in the tree with
Youth A for about an hour talking until he would come down. Staff
2 said the second incident he was involved in with Youth A was on
August 26, 2023. Staff 2 said he was working at Cedar Creek that
day however had spent some time with Youth A during the day.
Staff 2 said Youth A was reporting he was a “leader” at the
psychiatric ward and “missed” being there. Staff 2 said Youth A
told him the other youth in the hospital referred to him as “Jesus”
and stated he has “kissed girls” and was allowed to be
unsupervised on the unit and wanted to go back. Staff 2 said later
that evening he went back to Cedar Creek and began to receive
texts from Staff 6 to notify him she was talking with Youth A over
by the main building. Staff 2 said at first Staff 6 was reporting
Youth A was just frustrated and expressing his feelings
appropriately however around 11pm she texted she needed help
and he ran over to assist. Staff 2 said when he arrived Staff 6 and
Youth A were standing on the picnic table and Youth A had a
sweatshirt around his neck and around the rafter and was leaning
forward attempting to have the sweatshirt cut off his airway. Staff 2
said he immediately was able to get the sweatshirt from around
Youth A’s neck and laid him on the picnic table he had been
standing on and rolled him to his side. Staff 2 said Youth A was not
talking, had his eyes closed, but was breathing normally and was
moving his body. Staff 2 said the police arrived shortly after he got
5

Youth A down and Youth A sat up and was talking to the police
officer. Staff 2 said the police walked Youth A to the ambulance at
which time he returned to Cedar Creek. Staff 2 said Youth A has
had behavior plans and safety plans for staff to follow as well as
training provided to them on how to work with Youth A. Staff 2 said
Youth A can go from zero to hundred in a second and is very
unpredictable about what will “set him off”.
Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on August
31, 2023, in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 3 said she
has worked with Youth A since his placement at South Bluff and
has been involved in once incident with Youth A attempting
suicide. Staff 3 said on August 15, 2023, Youth A returned home
from football practice and was asked to clean his room and
complete his chore to which he immediately responded “I am sick
of this mental and verbal abuse! I am going to climb a tree and
hang myself!”. Staff 3 said Youth A left South Bluff and began
walking to the main building and she followed him attempting to
give him positive feedback and encourage him to make good
choices. Staff 3 said Youth A began cussing at her and ran back to
South Bluff. Staff 3 said she continued to follow Youth A and once
he got to the house he ran into his room and grabbed a pair of
pants and ran back outside towards the main building. Staff 3 said
she followed behind him however he was faster than she was, she
could see him wrapping the pants around his neck as he ran and
he went to the pavilion, jumped on a table and tied the other side
of the pants around the rafters. Staff 3 said because of Youth A’s
earlier statements and current actions she yelled for another staff
that was outside to assist and called 911 as she was running after
him. Staff 3 said she got to the pavilion shortly after Youth A and
Staff 4 arrived shortly after her. Staff 3 said she was offering
verbal encouragement to have Youth A stand up as he was
leaning into his pants to try to cut off his airflow however this was
not working so she grabbed Youth A’s legs and picked him up as
Staff 4 tried to untie the pants. Staff 3 said Staff 6 arrived and
began to help hold Youth A’s legs and lift him higher to release all
tension on the pants around his neck. Staff 3 said Staff 4 finally
got the pants from around Youth A’s neck and he fell to his knees
on the picnic table. Staff 3 said Youth A then crawled forward and
grabbed the grill brush and began to scrape his arm with it. Staff 3
said staff took the grill brush away and he sat up and the
ambulance arrived. Staff 3 said Youth A never lost consciousness
but looked like the color was draining out of his face. Staff 3 said
the paramedics took over with Youth A and ended up taking him to
the hospital for further evaluation. Staff 3 said she believes staff
have been provided all the training they need in order to respond
6

to Youth A’s behaviors. Staff 3 said each situation with Youth A can
be different depending on his actions and she feels she and other
staff have the tools to respond to his needs appropriately.
Staff 4 was interviewed via telephone on August 31, 2023, in
collaboration with the MDHHS worker. Staff 4 said she has
worked in South Bluff with Youth A since he was placed. Staff 4
said she picked Youth A up from football practice on August 15,
2023, and he seemed to be in a good mood. Staff 4 said Youth A
was told to complete his chore and clean his bedroom and then
could go outside to play basketball. Staff 4 said Youth A completed
his chore but did not clean his room entirely and so Staff 3 asked
him to finish it prior to going outside and he became very upset
stating “I’m not fucking vacuuming my floor”. Staff 4 said at that
time the other youth were finished with their responsibilities, so
she took them outside to the basketball court by the main building.
Staff 4 said Youth A began to follow her and the other youth and
Staff 3 also followed talking to Youth A about making good choices
and completing his chores. Staff 4 said Youth A became
increasingly upset and walked back to the house with Staff 3
following him. Staff 4 said a few moments later Youth A came back
out of the house with pants in his hands and Staff 3 following him.
Staff 4 said Youth A walked to the pavilion. She sent the group of
youth with her back into the house and ran over to the pavilion.
Staff 4 said when she arrived Youth A was standing on the table
and had the pants tied around the rafters, so she immediately got
on the table at which time he dropped his weight making the pants
cut off his airflow and he began to lose the color in his face. Staff 4
said she lifted him up and he did not fight against her getting the
pants from his neck and dropped to the picnic table. Staff 4 said
once on the picnic table Youth A began to crawl forward and
grabbed the grill brush and tried to cut his wrists, so she grabbed
the brush and threw it away from the pavilion at the same time the
police arrived. Staff 4 said the police took over talking to Youth A
and the paramedics arrived on scene and took Youth A into the
ambulance. Staff 4 said she then left and went back to South Bluff
to work on paperwork and check in with the other staff and youth.
Staff 4 said she did work with Youth A on both August 25, 2023,
and August 26, 2023. Staff 4 said Youth A was talking a lot about
liking Willow Creek better than South Bluff and wanting to go back
because he had made a lot of friends. Staff 4 said she was not
involved in the incident with Youth A on August 26, 2023. Staff 4
said she feels there has been good communication about Youth
A’s history, behavior plans, safety plans, and staff have been
provided with the training and tools in order to meet his needs.
7

Supervisor was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
August 31, 2023, in collaboration with the MDHHS worker.
Supervisor said he did not work directly with Youth A as he is the
supervisor of Cedar Creek. Supervisor said he was never on call
or involved in any of Youth A’s self-harm or suicidal attempts.
Therapist was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
August 31, 2023, in collaboration with the MDHHS worker.
Therapist said he is the Chief of Clinical Services and Youth A’s
direct therapist. Therapist said he had been meeting with Youth A
twice per week when he was at South Bluff. Therapist said he has
never been directly involved with Youth A during any of his self-
harm or suicide attempts, noting he “treats me differently than
other staff” and is “more open” when talking to Therapist.
Therapist said that a few weeks after Youth A was placed at South
Bluff he was in a tree when Therapist arrived at work however did
not speak to him during that situation and the police were called to
assist in getting him down from the tree. Therapist said Youth A
has a history of being abused by women and had the viewpoint
that everyone is sexist, and he would never take responsibility for
his statements or actions when it involved a female staff. Therapist
said it was his assessment that Youth A “does not want to die” and
uses suicide threats as a tool to manipulate people around him
into giving him what he wants or allowing him to do want he wants
to do. Therapist said Youth A told him that his prior attempts were
done out of “boredom or to get [Youth A] way”. Therapist said
when discussing whether or not Youth A would be allowed to
participate in football at the public school he attends, Therapist
brought up the concern of suicidal attempts to which Youth A
responded “why would I kill myself in front of the football team?
That’s embarrassing, I don’t want them to know my issues.”
Therapist said Youth A has always used strangulation as his
technique of choice however will only do it when staff are around
and in a place where he can stand up and release the tension
around his neck. Therapist said Youth A has climbed up on the
roof of the South Bluff house several times however it has always
been in an attention seeking manner. Therapist said despite Youth
A’s behaviors being assessed as attention seeking all staff have
been trained to take every threat seriously. Therapist said the staff
members have been provided with all of Youth A’s history and
have been trained specifically on tools to use with Youth A.
Therapist said he and Social Worker have developed behavior
plans and safety plans to give staff a tool to follow and provide
additional supervision and support for Youth A. Therapist stated
these plans specifically include supervision and not allowing Youth
A out of staff sight, restrictions on clothing items that Youth A is
8

allowed, and about hanging as that is Youth A’s method of choice.
Therapist said staff are provided with preservice training that
includes crisis management and there have been additional
trainings offered about suicide preventions. Therapist said upon
Youth A’s return to South Bluff he was making comments about
having kissed a girl at Willow Creek and wanting to go back to be
able to see her.
Chief Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the
facility on August 31, 2023, in collaboration with the MDHHS
worker. Chief Administrator said she was involved one time
during Youth A’s attempt to hang himself from the tree by the
playground. Chief Administrator said she arrived at the facility
about 8am and saw Youth A walking in the field area with Staff 6.
Chief Administrator said Youth A walked over to the tree and tied
the sweatshirt into a noose, jumped up on the tree branch to tie
the shirt and put his head in the noose and began to hang himself.
Chief Administrator said she was offering Youth A choices to talk
to her, staff, or Therapist and he had no response. Chief
Administrator said once Youth A got himself into the noose, she
grabbed his legs so he could not hang and got him out of the tree.
Chief Administrator said Therapist was driving into the parking lot
at this time and so he was called over to talk with Youth A while
Chief Administrator and Staff 6 observed from a distance. Chief
Administrator said Youth A got up from where he was sitting and
climbed back into the tree and refused to come down, so she
called emergency services for assistance. Chief Administrator said
Youth A was brought to the hospital and evaluated and then came
back to the facility. Chief Administrator was not directly involved in
any of the other incidents with Youth A.
Documents Reviewed:
• Incident Report dated July 16, 2023, regarding Youth A’s
attempt to hang himself on the gutter’s at the main building.
The incident report is consistent with Staff 5’s interview.
• Incident Report 160830205 dated August 15, 2023,
regarding Youth A’s attempt to hang himself at the pavilion.
The incident report is consistent with Staff 3’s interview.
• Incident Report dated August 26, 2023, regarding Youth
A’s attempt to hang himself from the pavilion. The incident
report is consistent with Staff 6’s interview.
• Youth A’s safety plan dated August 25, 2023. The safety
plan is signed by Social Worker, Youth A, and Therapist.
• Two Behavior Management Plan/Trauma Safety Plans for
Youth A. The plans were not dated however were different
plans for Youth A. According to Social Worker, one of the
9

plans was an updated version. The plans reviewed “child’s
current presentation, triggers, prevention tools, skill
building, and processing/problem solving-building and
using the safety plan”. The plans address Youth A’s self-
harm behaviors, increased supervision need, importance of
keeping Youth A’s environment free of safety risks such as
knives, pens, glass, scissors. The plans provide tools for
staff to use with Youth A such as providing positive
reinforcement when he is struggling with his emotions,
encouraging him to use his coping skills, ignoring attention-
seeking behaviors.
• Staff Training In-Service dated June 7, 2023, for “Suicide
Assessment, Management, and Intervention” attended by
four staff including, Chief Administrator, Therapist, and
Staff 6.
• Staff Training In-Service dated August 30, 2023, for
“Suicide Assessment, Management, and Treatment”
attended by thirteen staff including Staff 2, Staff 3, Staff 5,
Staff 6, Supervisor, Social Worker, and Chief Administrator.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance with Sufficiency of Staff. The
facility had developed behavior management plans and safety
plans for Youth A that all staff were aware of, trained on, and were
following. Youth A reported staff were always with him providing
supervision during the self-harm incidents. Staff reported always
providing supervision to Youth A however in certain situations
needing additional staff assistance with Youth A for which
additional staff have responded timely.
Technical Assistance:
The facility should date youth’s Behavior Management
Plans/Trauma Safety Plans to clearly indicate which plan is the
current plan for staff to follow as well as document when plans are
originally developed.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(e) Dispensing medication.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 8/25/23, youth was discharged from a psychiatric hospital and
was placed on a new medication regime. The staff members did
not charge youth’s medication and they continued to give youth
the old medication regime.
10

Investigation Interviews:
Complainant 1 was interviewed via telephone on August 31,
2023, in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Complainant 1 said
she did not have any additional information, noting that most of
the information came directly from Youth A.
Complainant 2 was interviewed via telephone on September
6, 2023. Complainant 2 did not have anything additional
information.
Youth A was interviewed via TEAMS on August 30, 2023, in
collaboration with the MDHHS worker. Youth A said when he
left Willow Creek Hospital on August 25, 2023, his Lexapro went
from 15mg to 20mg. Youth A said he told the South Bluff staff
stating he could not remember which staff he told, about his
medication change, but staff continued to give him his “old dose”.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility, on August
31, 2023, in collaboration with the MDHHS worker. Staff 1 said
she has not passed Youth A medications since July 2023 and at
that time she recalled Youth A only being on a nasal spray and
allergy medication. Staff 1 said Social Worker is the person who
“takes care of medications” for the youth.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility, on August
31, 2023, in collaboration with the MDHHS worker. Staff 2 said
he transferred from South Bluff to Cedar Creek the beginning of
August 2023 and therefore has not passed medications to Youth A
since that time. Staff 2 said he is not aware of Youth A’s current
medication regime.
Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on August
31, 2023, in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 3 said she
did not pass any of Youth A’s medications once he came back to
South Bluff on August 25, 2023.
Staff 4 was interviewed via telephone on August 31, 2023, in
collaboration with the MDHHS worker. Staff 4 said she has no
knowledge of any medication changes for Youth A from August 25,
2023.
Supervisor was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
August 31, 2023, in collaboration with the MDHHS worker.
Supervisor said he works in Cedar Creek home however did go
with Therapist to pick Youth A up from Willow Creek Psychiatric
Hospital on August 25, 2023. Supervisor said he met with the
11

Willow Creek staff to complete Youth A’s discharge. Supervisor
said Willow Creek staff noted an increase in Youth A’s lithium from
900mg to 1200mg which Youth A denied during the meeting and
the Willow Creek staff said she was “unsure” about the switch
because she never worked nights when the medications were
distributed. Supervisor said Willow Creek staff only noted the
change with the lithium and no other medications. Supervisor said
he was given a yellow folder with paperwork in it which he gave
directly to Therapist. Supervisor said he never looked in the folder
to see what was in it. Supervisor said Youth A talked about his
frustrations with his lithium dose during the drive home but never
mentioned any other medication changes.
Therapist was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
August 31, 2023, in collaboration with the MDHHS worker.
Therapist said he and Supervisor picked Youth A up on August 25,
2023, from Willow Creek Psychiatric Hospital. Therapist said the
Willow Creek staff asked who wanted to participate in the
discharge discussion and it was decided Supervisor would.
Therapist said he waited in the waiting room during the discharge
meeting. Therapist said once the meeting was done, Supervisor
and Youth A came out and they drove back to South Bluff.
Therapist said Supervisor handed him a yellow folder with the
discharge information inside it and he never opened the folder or
reviewed any of the paperwork. Therapist denied Supervisor
telling him anything about the discharge meeting but rather they
“talked socially” during the ride back to South Bluff and once there
Supervisor left and he took Youth A inside. Therapist said he put
the yellow folder with the discharge paperwork on the staff desk at
South Bluff. Therapist said Social Worker had developed a safety
plan that the staff had printed out so he reviewed that plan with
Youth A and had him sign it and left. Therapist said to his
knowledge no one looked at the discharge paperwork until
Monday, by which time Youth A was already placed back at Willow
Creek due to another suicide attempt. Therapist said he had no
knowledge that Youth A’s medication had been changed and a
prescription had been called into Walgreens for the new
medication because he never read the discharge paperwork.
Chief Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the
facility on August 31, 2023, in collaboration with the MDHHS
worker. Chief Administrator said the facility does not have a
formal written protocol in place for who is to review discharge
paperwork and ensure the requirements of the hospital are met
upon return to the facility. Chief Administrator said it would have
12

been her expectation in this situation that Therapist would have
reviewed the discharge paperwork.
Documents Reviewed:
• Youth A’ s discharge documentation from Willow Creek
Hospital:
- Discharge Safety Plan for Youth A from Willow Creek
which outlined Youth A’s “warning signs, coping strategy,
distraction, and help”. This document stated it was
reviewed with Youth A.
